SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: Why does the author put “hooked” and “getting it” in quotation marks?

A.Choice: to show that the words are slang

B.Choice: to quote someone

C.Choice: to define the words

D.Choice: to prove that the words apply to math

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Ideas & Analysis
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: What argument is the author making in paragraph 3?

A.Choice: Mathematics is mostly theoretical rather than practical.

B.Choice: Mathematics has relationships to both art and music.

C.Choice: Mathematics can be fun, but can be used for many purposes.

D.Choice: Mathematics appeals mostly to people who do well in math.

SubTopics: Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: What is the reason the author adds the phrase “(smile here)” to the sentence in paragraph 3?

A.Choice: because many students think math is pointless

B.Choice: because the author really likes math

C.Choice: because several unlikely ideas are stressed

D.Choice: because math can be a funny topic

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 7 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.
Content: What does the word “parallel” in paragraph 4 suggest about the concepts?

A.Choice: They are opposite in nature.

B.Choice: They are written on the same line of the page.

C.Choice: They are both used in advanced mathematics.

D.Choice: They are similar in what they mean.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: What do the people quoted in the text have in common?

A.Choice: They focus on practical uses of math.

B.Choice: They became interested in math early in life.

C.Choice: They get pleasure from math.

D.Choice: They are all famous philosophers.

SubTopics: Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: What effect do the quotes from other people have on the author’s purpose for the text?

A.Choice: They help to prove the author’s point that the world of math can be fun and beautiful.

B.Choice: They are included to provide background information about the history of some famous math scholars.

C.Choice: They serve as a reminder of how important it is to study mathematics in school.

D.Choice: They illustrate that all of the different areas of math study are crucial to becoming a mathematician.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: What is the meaning of the word “infinite” in paragraph 6?

A.Choice: the highest number that has ever been calculated

B.Choice: greater than any measurable amount

C.Choice: the largest number at the end of a number line

D.Choice: smaller than can be seen by humans

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: What is the “spirit of math” in the text?

A.Choice: solving only problems that are easy

B.Choice: worrying about whether math is useful

C.Choice: being willing to do things one step at a time

D.Choice: trying hard and thinking problems through

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which statement summarizes the plot of the selection?

A.Choice: Hester was a man who used his prior knowledge of bears to creatively earn money.

B.Choice: Hester lied about his background and unfairly cheated the fairground out of $225.

C.Choice: Hester was desperate, so he foolishly put his life at risk.

D.Choice: Hester’s crops failed because he did not properly care for them.

SubTopics: Analyze how a drama’s or poem’s (or other literary genre’s) form or structure contributes to its meaning.
Content: Why does the author include the introduction to the selection?

A.Choice: to introduce the setting of the selection

B.Choice: to provide background information about the main character

C.Choice: to give specific details about the bear in the wrestling cage

D.Choice: to provide knowledge of what happens to the bear

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text; analyze the impact of rhymes and repetitions of sounds on meaning and tone in a specific line or section of a literary work.
Content: What do the “bright lights of Landsburg” represent for Hester King as he leaves his home?

A.Choice: They represent a dependable person who will lead the way.

B.Choice: They represent a chance to seek safe entertainment.

C.Choice: They represent a risky experience that awaits him.

D.Choice: They represent an opportunity to solve a problem.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story or drama interact.
Content: What is the reason that Hester left without telling Mollie where he was going?

A.Choice: Mollie would want to come along, too.

B.Choice: Mollie would be afraid of the danger.

C.Choice: Mollie would want him to get a job.

D.Choice: Mollie would tell him to take the kids with him.

SubTopics: Interpret figures of speech in context based on grade 7 reading and content.
Content: What does the phrase “clinched with Old Bruin” mean in paragraph 49?

A.Choice: Hester and the bear were helping each other.

B.Choice: Hester and the bear were hurting each other.

C.Choice: Hester and the bear were hitting each other.

D.Choice: Hester and the bear were hugging each other.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: How does Hester defeat Bruin in the cage?

A.Choice: He injures the animal so it cannot fight.

B.Choice: He uses information that he learned as a child.

C.Choice: He pretends to be asleep, and he is left alone.

D.Choice: He frightens the animal because he yells at it.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular elements of a story or drama interact.
Content: How does the setting of the selection shape the plot?

A.Choice: The country fair provides the arena for the conflict and the resolution.

B.Choice: The countryside provides the suspense for the characters and the action.

C.Choice: The country fair sets up the details that foreshadow the main problem.

D.Choice: The countryside represents the emotional reactions felt by the characters.

SubTopics: Determine two or more central ideas in a text and analyze their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: What is the central idea of the text?

A.Choice: how the postal service adapted to the Civil War

B.Choice: how the Union control of the mail affected the Confederacy

C.Choice: the role of the postal service during the Civil War

D.Choice: the importance of mail for Confederate soldiers

SubTopics: Determine two or more central ideas in a text and analyze their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which is a summary of the section entitled “Crossing the Border”?

A.Choice: It details how many ships were used as blockade runners during the Civil War.

B.Choice: It explains why ship mail was so expensive during the Civil War.

C.Choice: It describes how mail was transported from the North to the South during most of the Civil War.

D.Choice: It defines the role of the ship’s master as the new postmaster of the Confederate Post Office Department.

SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: How does the section entitled “The Confederate Postal System” contribute to the understanding of the title?

A.Choice: The section explains why the United States Postal Service could not produce stamps during the Civil War.

B.Choice: The section describes the characteristics of the first postmaster general, John H. Reagan.

C.Choice: The section describes why ships were needed by the United States Postal Service.

D.Choice: The section explains that the Confederate states started their own postal system during the Civil War.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: The section explains that the Confederate states started their own postal system during the Civil War.

A.Choice: The stamp designs had to be imported from England.

B.Choice: The typical stamp printers were all located in the North.

C.Choice: All of the reliable stamp printers were housed in the South.

D.Choice: No one could decide on a design for the stamp.

SubTopics: Interpret figures of speech in context based on grade 7 reading and content.
Content: What does the phrase “first-person depictions of battles” mean in paragraph 12?

A.Choice: direct participation in the battles themselves

B.Choice: permission to send letters about battles

C.Choice: battles seen through the eyes of the men fighting

D.Choice: recorded sounds of the battles

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Ideas & Analysis
SubTopics: Trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims.
Content: How does the author support the claim that the U.S. Mail tried to assist the communications between the soldiers and their loved ones?

A.Choice: The soldiers had to send their letters through certain cities.

B.Choice: The soldiers needed to have special stamps for their letters.

C.Choice: The soldiers did not have to pay for stamps to send their letters.

D.Choice: The soldiers sent their letters on specially designed ships.

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text.
Content: How did the Civil War influence the mail service?

A.Choice: Mail service was difficult and slow, but it persevered.

B.Choice: Mail service was carefully controlled and never faltered.

C.Choice: Mail service was inept, expensive, and rarely successful.

D.Choice: Mail service was interrupted for the duration of the war.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which statement is supported by information in the text?

A.Choice: The Union postal system played an important role in ending the Civil War.

B.Choice: The Confederacy ran a successful mail program with Union support.

C.Choice: The Union postal system lacked resources to support the Confederacy.

D.Choice: The Union limited the Confederacy’s ability to send mail.

SubTopics: Determine two or more central ideas in a text and analyze their development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which quote summarizes the author’s frustrations about his first journey at sea?

A.Choice: “I was, no doubt, known for a landsman by everyone on board as soon as I hove in sight.”

B.Choice: “ ‘With all my imperfections on my head,’ I joined the crew.”

C.Choice: “There is not so helpless and pitiable an object in the world as a landsman beginning a sailor’s life.”

D.Choice: “This was literally bidding good night to my native land.”

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: How does paragraph 1 contribute to the development of the overall text?

A.Choice: It vividly describes the setting.

B.Choice: It explains the motivation of the narrator.

C.Choice: It links the main characters to the plot.

D.Choice: It provides background information about the ship.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: What does the phrase “full sea-rig” mean in paragraph 1?

A.Choice: the name of a sailing vessel

B.Choice: the name of the ship’s captain

C.Choice: a part of the ship’s deck

D.Choice: a uniform worn by sailors

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: What is one way to identify a beginner sailor?

A.Choice: The beginner has a lot of checked shirts.

B.Choice: The beginner has sunburnt cheeks.

C.Choice: The beginner has toughened hands.

D.Choice: The beginner has untanned skin.

SubTopics: Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others.
Content: What was the difference between the author’s and the old salt’s first night on watch?

A.Choice: The narrator was a green hand and too afraid to walk about the ship, but the old salt walked fore and aft.

B.Choice: The narrator wore his clothes like a green hand, but the old salt’s clothes were peculiar.

C.Choice: The narrator stayed awake the entire night, but the old salt went to sleep.

D.Choice: The narrator was a sufficient lookout, but the old salt was much better.

SubTopics: Analyze the interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in a text.
Content: What made the “old salt” so carefree upon his takeover of the watch post?

A.Choice: the fact that he was an inexperienced sailor

B.Choice: the fact that the ship was anchored in a safe harbor

C.Choice: the fact that he knew others would assist him

D.Choice: the fact that he felt everyone was afraid of him

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: What is conveyed when the narrator says they “began beating down the bay” in paragraph 4?

A.Choice: The crew was fighting large waves.

B.Choice: The ship started moving in the water.

C.Choice: The crew was swimming vigorously.

D.Choice: The ship was in danger of sinking.

SubTopics: Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas.
Content: What strategy does the author use to bring the new, young sailor to life?

A.Choice: the use of first-person narrative

B.Choice: the use of third-person narrative

C.Choice: the use of quotes and dialogue

D.Choice: the use of memories and diaries

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which lines from the poem provide the strongest support for the theme of renewal?

A.Choice: “There’s something seems to say / That winter’s had its day.”

B.Choice: “And the elder branches show / Their buds against the snow.”

C.Choice: “So, silently but swift, / Above the wintry drift,”

D.Choice: “We see the bloom of birth / Make young again the earth.”

SubTopics: Analyze how a drama’s or poem’s (or other literary genre’s) form or structure contributes to its meaning.
Content: How does the first stanza contribute to the meaning of the poem?

A.Choice: It introduces the idea that a difference can be felt all around.

B.Choice: It emphasizes the fact that spring is coming later this year.

C.Choice: It introduces the idea that the weather is constantly changing.

D.Choice: It emphasizes the fact that this past winter has been harsh.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: What can be inferred from lines 5–6?

A.Choice: The speaker thinks the spring sky is filled with more white clouds than a winter sky.

B.Choice: The speaker feels so tired of the winter cold that she hopes spring comes very quickly.

C.Choice: The speaker thinks the shade of blue in the spring sky is different than that of a winter sky.

D.Choice: The speaker feels so in tune with the weather that she can feel the change of seasons.

SubTopics: Analyze how an author develops and contrasts the perspectives of different characters in a text.
Content: Which lines reveal the speaker’s contrasting perspectives regarding winter and spring?

A.Choice: “There’s something too that’s new / In the color of the blue / That’s in the morning sky, / Before the sun is high.”

B.Choice: “And though on plain and hill, / ’Tis winter, winter still, / There’s something seems to say / That winter’s had its day.”

C.Choice: “And all this changing tint, / This whispering stir and hint / Of bud and bloom and wing, / Is the coming of the spring.”

D.Choice: “And tomorrow or today / The brooks will break away / From their icy, frozen sleep / And run and laugh and leap.”

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 7 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.
Content: What does “drift” mean in line 30?

A.Choice: a sudden movement

B.Choice: a wild gust of wind

C.Choice: a large pile of snow

D.Choice: a sloping mountain

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which statement provides an objective summary of the selection?

A.Choice: Atalanta wishes to marry and have an extravagant wedding, and asks princes to compete for her hand. A man named Young John wins the competition, and Atalanta deems him worthy to marry her.

B.Choice: Atalanta wants to be married, but cannot find a desirable person to marry her. Young John wins the right to marry Atalanta, but in the end, they decide to wait until after they have traveled the world for a year.

C.Choice: Atalanta’s father, the king, wants his daughter to marry a prince, but she refuses to consider anyone. The king decides that Young John will be a suitable husband for Atalanta instead, and Atalanta agrees after much negotiation.

D.Choice: Atalanta’s father, the king, wants his daughter to marry, but she does not want to do so. The king decides to have people race to win the right to marry Atalanta, so she competes, wins, and chooses to remain unmarried.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text; analyze the impact of rhymes and repetitions of sounds on meaning and tone in a specific line or section of a literary work.
Content: How does the repetition of the word “powerful” in paragraphs 3 and 7 affect the tone of the selection?

A.Choice: It creates a tone of hope.

B.Choice: It creates a tone of authority.

C.Choice: It creates a tone of frustration.

D.Choice: It creates a tone of excitement.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text; analyze the impact of rhymes and repetitions of sounds on meaning and tone in a specific line or section of a literary work.
Content: How does the phrase “clever girl” affect the meaning of paragraph 8?

A.Choice: It suggests that Atalanta is creative in opposing the king’s race.

B.Choice: It suggests that Atalanta is excited about running in the king’s race.

C.Choice: It suggests that Atalanta is suspicious of her competitors in the king’s race.

D.Choice: It suggests that Atalanta is nervous about running in the king’s race.

SubTopics: Analyze how an author develops and contrasts the perspectives of different characters in a text.
Content: Which quote shows the contrast between Young John’s perspective and that of the king?

A.Choice: “Young John saw the princess only from a distance, but near enough to know how bright and clever she was. He wished very much to race with her, to win, and to earn the right to talk with her and become her friend.”

B.Choice: “ ‘For surely,’ he said to himself, ‘it is not right for Atalanta’s father to give her away to the winner of the race. Atalanta herself must choose the person she wants to marry, or whether she wishes to marry at all.’ ”

C.Choice: “ ‘Not one of them,’ she said to herself, ‘can win the race, for I will run fast as the wind and leave them all behind.’ And now a bugle sounded, a flag was dropped, and the runners were off!”

D.Choice: “Atalanta raced even faster to pull ahead, but Young John was a strong match for her. Smiling with the pleasure of the race, Atalanta and Young John reached the finish line together, and together they broke through the golden ribbon.”

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which quote supports the inference that the king had little confidence in Atalanta’s skill as a runner?

A.Choice: “Once upon a time, not long ago, there lived a princess named Atalanta, who could run as fast as the wind.”

B.Choice: “ ‘You don’t have to choose, Father,’ Atalanta said. ‘I will choose. And I’m not sure that I will choose to marry anyone at all.’ ”

C.Choice: “The king rose to address them all. ‘Good day,’ he said to the crowds. ‘Good luck,’ he said to the young men. To Atalanta he said, ‘Good-bye. I must tell you farewell, for tomorrow you will be married.’ ”

D.Choice: “Soon another young man, tense with the effort, drew near to Atalanta. He reached out as though to touch her sleeve, stumbled for an instant, and lost speed.”

SubTopics: Interpret figures of speech in context based on grade 7 reading and content.
Content: How does the simile “run fast as the wind” in paragraph 19 influence the theme?

A.Choice: It suggests that the setting is cool and windy.

B.Choice: It creates a lighthearted and fun tone.

C.Choice: It shows that the runners are training with great effort.

D.Choice: It supports the ideas of freedom and independence.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: What can be inferred about Young John, based on paragraph 28?

A.Choice: He is honorable and thoughtful.

B.Choice: He is rude and selfish.

C.Choice: He is arrogant and childish.

D.Choice: He is brave and clever.

SubTopics: Cite several pieces of textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: What do Atalanta and Young John have in common?

A.Choice: They are curious about the world.

B.Choice: They never want to get married.

C.Choice: They hope to find love elsewhere.

D.Choice: They are committed to their studies.
